Award.AwardTitle: WORKSHOP: New Perspectives in Legal Geography - at NSF - Fall of 2012

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The past decade has witnessed a surge of scientific inquiry on aspects of legal geography, including work by human geographers and legal scholars as well as sociologists, criminologists, and anthropologists, among others. This area of research has historically addressed the spatial and human dynamics surrounding various legal phenomena, including property, racial segregation and discrimination, policing practices, prison settings, and various other relevant aspects of society (urban, home, borders, etc.). The proposed workshop will advance the study of legal geography by exploring several new perspectives on spatiality. The present focus engages contemporary spatial theory to expand conceptions of space to include the domains of meaning, representation, discourse, and ideology. In this context, the proposed workshop will encourage collaboration in new areas of socio-legal inquiry, including environmental, civil rights, immigration, international, punishment, intellectual property, and labor laws.

The workshop will bring together social and spatial scientists, and legal scholars, to discuss these new perspectives and to explore diverse methodological approaches to addressing such issues. The intellectual merit of this workshop proposal rests on its ability to engage an emerging field of interdisciplinary social science and the law, and to encourage further social and spatial science theory that might enhance our understanding of the development and implementation of law. The workshop will promote the inclusion of junior scholars in this area, and has great potential for improving the training and practice of law.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of the workshop was to enhance collaboration among scholars who are interested in furthering the project of legal geography. Legal geography can be thought of as analogous to legal history of legal sociology in that it seeks to advance interdisciplinary research in law as a social pheneomena. Unlike legal history or legal sociology, however, legal geography is a relatively new endeavor lacking institutional structures. As it had developed over the last decade  distinctions have arisen between those scholars more interested in theory and those more interested in applied or empirical work and sharper distinctions between those who identify primarily as human geographers and those who identify as legal scholars and teach in law schools. These fractures have impeded progress in legal geography. The purpose of the workshop was to break down some of the impediments to cross-disciplinary conversation. While the workshops did succeed in forming the basis for on-going collaborations - for example, panels planned for upcoming meetins of the Law and Society Association and the Association of American Geographers it also became apparent that there are structural - institutional obsticals that inhibit greater collaboration and foster disciplinary separatism. These are related to such things differential tenure and promotional norms between law schools and academic departments, the value of publishing outside of ones home discipline and so on. Nevertheless, avenues for enhanced interdisciplinary work are open.
